instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the metabolomic analysis in predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)?
Output: The metabolomic analysis in the related study used two types of spectra: nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and mass spectrometry (MS).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the metabolomic analysis in predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)?
Output: Sum-to-one normalization and z-score normalization were used in the metabolomic analysis for predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the diagnostic performance of the metabolite sets in the metabolomic analysis in predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the diagnostic performance of the metabolite sets was the area under the receiver operating characteristics curve (AUC).

instruction: What machine learning models were used to predict IUGR in the metabolomic analysis in predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)?
Output: The machine learning models used to predict IUGR in the metabolomic analysis were Correlation-based feature selection (CFS), Partial least squares regression (PLS), Learning Vector Quantization (LVQ), and support vector machine (SVM) models.

instruction: Can the use of spectroscopic methods in metabolomic analysis provide superior accuracy in predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) compared to traditional methods, as demonstrated in the related study?
Output: Yes, the use of spectroscopic methods in metabolomic analysis, specifically nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and mass spectrometry (MS), demonstrated superior accuracy in predicting intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) compared to traditional methods in the related study. The study utilized MS and NMR-based metabolomic analysis on cord blood serum samples from 40 IUGR cases and 40 controls. Three variable selection algorithms (Correlation-based feature selection, Partial least squares regression, and Learning Vector Quantization) were tested for their diagnostic performance. The selected set of metabolites, including an overlapping set identified by the three algorithms, achieved statistically significant accuracies in the range of 0.78-0.82 for their optimized support vector machine (SVM) models. The model utilizing all metabolites in the dataset had an AUC of 0.91, with a sensitivity of 0.83 and specificity of 0.80. This indicates that the spectroscopic methods used in metabolomic analysis provided superior accuracy in predicting IUGR compared to traditional methods.
